chest – this affects about 15% of people with acne
blackheads – small black or yellowish bumps that develop on the skin; they're not filled with dirt, but are black because the inner lining of the hair follicle produces colour
whiteheads – have a similar appearance to blackheads, but may be firmer and will not empty when squeezed
papules – small red bumps that may feel tender or sore
pustules – similar to papules, but have a white tip in the centre, caused by a build-up of pus
nodules – large hard lumps that build up beneath the surface of the skin and can be painful
cysts – the most severe type of spot caused by acne; they're large pus-filled lumps that look similar toboilsand carry the greatest risk of causing permanentscarring

name: Actinic keratoses (solar keratoses)
symptoms: can feel dry, rough and scaly, or like sandpaper
are usually between 1cm and 2cm in size
can be the same colour as your skin, or range from pink to red to brown

name: Addison's disease
symptoms: loss of appetite and unintentional weight loss

name: Adenomyosis
symptoms: pelvic pain (pain in the lower part of your tummy)
bloating, heaviness or fullness in your tummy (abdomen)

name: Alcohol misuse
symptoms: you feel you should cut down on your drinking
other people have been criticising your drinking
you feel guilty or bad about your drinking
you need a drink first thing in the morning to steady your nerves or get rid of a hangover
they regularly drink more than 14 units of alcohol a week
they're sometimes unable to remember what happened the night before because of their drinking
they fail to do what was expected of them as a result of their drinking (for example, missing an appointment or work because they're drunk or hungover)

name: Alcohol poisoning
symptoms: slurring words or being unable to speak
being unable to coordinate movement, for example, being unable to stand, walk, or pick things up
pale or blue-tinged skin - on black or brown skin this may be easier to see inside the lips, on the gums and under the fingernails

name: Alcohol-related liver disease
symptoms: yellowing of the whites of the eyes or skin (jaundice)
swelling in the ankles and tummy
vomiting blood or passing blood in your stools

name: Allergic rhinitis
symptoms: the roof of your mouth being itchy

name: Allergies
symptoms: pain or tenderness around your cheeks, eyes or forehead
itchy skin or a raised rash (hives)
swollen eyes, lips, mouth or throat

name: Amblyopia, see Lazy eye
symptoms: shutting 1 eye or squinting when looking at things
not being able to follow an object or person with your eyes
tilting your head when looking at something
having tired eyes and rubbing your eyes a lot
tripping or falling over a lot

name: Amyloidosis
symptoms: a fast or slow heartbeat or chest pain, if your heart is affected
loss of appetite, feeling or being sick, diarrhoea or constipation, if your digestive system is affected
frothy pee, if your kidneys are affected
pain, numbness or tingling in your hands and feet, if your nerves are affected

name: Anaemia (iron deficiency), see Iron deficiency anaemia
symptoms: hearing ringing, buzzing or hissing noises inside your head (tinnitus)
hair loss – you notice more hair coming out when brushing or washing it
wanting to eat non-food items, such as paper or ice (pica)
painful open sores (ulcers) in the corners of your mouth

name: Anaemia (vitamin B12 or folate deficiency), see Vitamin B12 or folate deficiency anaemia
symptoms: psychological problems, which can range from milddepressionor anxiety to confusion and dementia
problems with memory, understanding and judgement

name: Anal fissure
symptoms: a sharp pain when you poo, often followed by a deep burning pain that may last several hours
bleeding when you poo – most people notice a small amount of bright red blood either in their poo or on the toilet paper

name: Anaphylaxis
symptoms: swelling of your throat and tongue
difficulty breathing or breathing very fast
difficulty swallowing, tightness in your throat or a hoarse voice
skin that feels cold to the touch
blue, grey or pale skin, lips or tongue – if you have brown or black skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of your hands or soles of your feet

name: Aneurysm (abdominal aortic), see Abdominal aortic aneurysm
symptoms: a pulsing feeling in your tummy

name: Angina
symptoms: feels tight, dull or heavy – it may spread to your arms, neck, jaw or back
is triggered by physical exertion or stress
stops within a few minutes of resting

name: Angioedema
symptoms: the face – particularly the lips, tongue and eyelids

name: Arthritis
symptoms: inflammation in and around the joints
warm red skin over the affected joint

name: Asbestosis
symptoms: pain in your chest or shoulder
in more advanced cases, clubbed (swollen) fingertips

name: Asthma
symptoms: a tight chest, which may feel like a band is tightening around it

name: Atherosclerosis
symptoms: pain in your arms and legs, especially when exercising

name: Auditory processing disorder (APD)
symptoms: people with strong accents or fast talkers

name: Bacterial vaginosis
symptoms: an unusual vaginal discharge that has a strong fishy smell, particularly after sex
a change to the colour and consistency of your discharge, such as becoming greyish-white and thin and watery

name: Balanitis
symptoms: a thick discharge that comes from under your foreskin
difficulty pulling back your foreskin – though in young children it's normal to have a tight foreskin

name: Bedbugs
symptoms: bites – often on skin exposed while sleeping, like the face, neck and arms
spots of blood on your bedding – from the bites or from squashing a bedbug
small brown spots on bedding or furniture (bedbug poo)

name: Bell's palsy
symptoms: weakness on 1 side of your face, or not being able to move 1 side of your face – this usually happens over a few days
a drooping eyelid or corner of your mouth

name: Bladder pain syndrome (interstitial cystitis)
symptoms: intensepelvic pain(felt over your lower tummy)
needing to pee more often than usual
pain in your lower tummy when your bladder is filling up, which is relieved when you pee
waking up several times during the night to pee

name: Bleeding from the bottom (rectal bleeding)
symptoms: red streaks on the outside of your poo
pink water in the toilet bowl
blood in your poo or bloody diarrhoea
very dark poo (this can be blood mixed in poo)

name: Blepharitis
symptoms: a gritty feeling in the eyes
flakes or crusts around the roots of the eyelashes
eyelids sticking together in the morning when you wake up

name: Bloating
symptoms: your tummy feels full or bigger than usual
you have tummy pain or discomfort
your tummy is rumbling or making noises

name: Blood poisoning, see Sepsis
symptoms: blue, grey, pale or blotchy skin, lips or tongue – on brown or black skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of the hands or soles of the feet
a rash that does not fade when you roll a glass over it, the same asmeningitis
difficulty breathing (you may notice grunting noises or their stomach sucking under their ribcage), breathlessness or breathing very fast
a weak, high-pitched cry that's not like their normal cry
not responding like they normally do, or not interested in feeding or normal activities
being sleepier than normal or difficult to wake
acting confused, slurred speech or not making sense
blue, grey, pale or blotchy skin, lips or tongue – on brown or black skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of the hands or soles of the feet
a rash that does not fade when you roll a glass over it, the same asmeningitis
difficulty breathing, breathlessness or breathing very fast
feels very unwell or like there's something seriously wrong
has not had a pee all day (for adults and older children) or in the last 12 hours (for babies and young children)
keeps vomiting and cannot keep any food or milk down (for babies and young children)
has swelling or pain around a cut or wound
has a very high or low temperature, feels hot or cold to the touch, or is shivering

name: Blood pressure (low), see Low blood pressure (hypotension)
Blue or grey skin or lips (cyanosis)
symptoms: skin (black or brown skin may turn grey - this may be easier to see on the palms of the hands, soles of the feet, lips, gums and inside the eyelids)

name: Body dysmorphic disorder (BDD)
symptoms: worry a lot about a specific area of your body (particularly your face)
spend a lot of time comparing your looks with other people's
look at yourself in mirrors a lot or avoid mirrors altogether
go to a lot of effort to conceal flaws – for example, by spending a long time combing your hair, applying make-up or choosing clothes
pick at your skin to make it "smooth"

name: Bone cyst
symptoms: pain, swelling or a lump, usually in your arm, leg or spine
numbness or tingling, if the cyst affects your spine
a break (fracture), sometimes from a relatively minor injury

name: Bowel polyps
symptoms: a small amount of slime (mucus) or blood in your poo
a change in your normal bowel habits, such as diarrhoea or constipation

name: Brain tumours
symptoms: persistently feeling sick (nausea), being sick (vomiting) and drowsiness
mental or behavioural changes, such as memory problems or changes in personality
progressive weakness orparalysison one side of the body

name: Breast abscess
symptoms: a lump or swelling in your breast
pain in your breast, it may also feel warm or look red (this may be harder to see on brown or black skin)

name: Breath-holding in babies and children
symptoms: cry and then be silent while holding their breath
open their mouth as if going to cry but make no sound
be floppy or stiff, or their body may jerk
usually last for less than 1 minute (if the child faints, they'll usually regain consciousness within 1 or 2 minutes)

name: Broken collarbone
symptoms: has bone sticking out of the skin

name: Broken hip
symptoms: pain in the hip or upper leg
swelling and bruising around your hip and upper leg
not being able to stand or put weight on the affected hip and leg
difficulty moving your hip and leg
the affected leg is at an odd angle or is shorter than the unaffected leg

name: Broken nose
symptoms: a crunching or crackling sound when you touch your nose
difficulty breathing through your nose – it might feel blocked
your nose changing shape – for example, it's not as straight as before

name: Broken or bruised ribs
symptoms: strong pain in your chest area, particularly when you breathe in or cough
swelling or tenderness around the affected ribs
feeling or hearing a crack if it's a broken rib

name: Bronchiolitis
symptoms: finding it difficult to feed or eat

name: Bronchitis
symptoms: a cough – you may cough up clear, white, yellow or green mucus

name: Bruxism, see Teeth grinding (bruxism)
symptoms: a painful jaw, which can lead to a condition calledtemporomandibular disorder (TMD)
worn-down or broken teeth, which can cause increased sensitivity and loss of teeth and fillings

name: Bulging eyes (exophthalmos)
symptoms: your eyes seem to be sticking out more than usual
you can see less of your upper eye lids (your eyes might look like they’re open very wide)
you can see more of the whites of your eyes
pain or problems closing your eyes or moving them around
dry eyes or feeling like there’s dirt or grit in them
your eyes hurt when looking at bright lights

name: Bursitis
symptoms: painful – usually a dull, achy pain
tender or warmer than surrounding skin
more painful when you move it or press on it

name: Buttock pain, see Sciatica
symptoms: painful – the pain may be stabbing, burning or shooting

name: Carpal tunnel syndrome
symptoms: an ache or pain in your fingers, hand or arm
a weak thumb or difficulty gripping

name: Catarrh
symptoms: feeling like there's a lump or something stuck in your throat
a frequent need to swallow or cough to try to clear your throat
a feeling that mucus is slowly dripping down the back of your throat (postnasal drip)
a crackling feeling in your ears

name: Cervical spondylosis
symptoms: neck and shoulder pain or stiffness that can come and go
headaches that often start at the back of the neck

name: Charles Bonnet syndrome
symptoms: be patterns such as shapes or lines
be of people, animals, objects or places
be in black and white or colour
last for a few minutes or several hours

name: Chest infection
symptoms: a chestycough– you may cough up green or yellow mucus

name: Chickenpox
symptoms: be anywhere on the body, including inside the mouth and around the genitals, which can be painful
spread or stay in a small area
be red, pink, darker or the same colour as surrounding skin, depending on your skin tone
be harder to see on brown and black skin
1: White skin with stage 1 of the chickenpox rash (thumbnail).1
2: Light brown skin with stage 1 of the chickenpox (thumbnail).2
3: Light brown skin with stage 1 of the chickenpox rash (thumbnail).3
1: White skin with stage 2 of the chickenpox rash (thumbnail).1
2: Medium brown skin with stage 2 of the chickenpox rash (thumbnail).2
3: Medium brown skin with stage 2 of the chickenpox rash (thumbnail).3
4: Dark brown skin with stage 2 of the chickenpox rash (thumbnail).4
1: White skin with stage 3 of the chickenpox rash (thumbnail).1
2: Light brown skin with stage 3 of the chickenpox rash (thumbnail).2
3: Medium brown skin with stage 3 of the chickenpox rash (thumbnail).3
aches and pains, and generally feeling unwell

name: Chlamydia
symptoms: unusual discharge from the vagina, penis or bottom
in women, pain in the tummy, bleeding after sex and bleeding between periods
in men, pain and swelling in the testicles

name: Chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS), see Myalgic encephalomyelitis or chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS)
symptoms: feeling extremely tired all the time – you may find it very hard to do daily activities
still feeling tired after resting or sleeping
taking a long time to recover after physical activity
problems sleeping, such as waking up often during the night
problems with thinking, memory and concentration

name: Chronic traumatic encephalopathy
symptoms: mood changes, such asdepressionor suicidal thoughts
behaviour changes, such as aggression and mood swings
confusion, such as getting lost or not knowing what time of day it is

name: Cirrhosis
symptoms: get red patches on your palms and small, spider-like blood vessels on your skin (spider angiomas) above waist level
yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes(jaundice)
swollen legs(oedema)or tummy (ascites) from a build-up of fluid

name: Cluster headaches
symptoms: a sharp, burning or piercing pain, usually on 1 side of the head, around the eye
headaches that happen at the same time of year or at set times of the day
headaches that start and stop quickly, without warning
pain that can make you feel restless, you may want to walk around or move your body
headaches that last between 15 minutes and 3 hours
a red and watering eye on the same side as the pain
drooping and swelling in the eyelid on the same side as the pain
a smaller pupil in the eye on the same side as the pain

name: Coccyx pain, see Tailbone (coccyx) pain
symptoms: when you sit down or stand up

name: Coeliac disease
symptoms: diarrhoea, which may smell particularly unpleasant
tiredness (fatigue)as a result of not getting enough nutrients from food (malnutrition)
disorders that affect co-ordination, balance and speech (ataxia)

name: Colic
symptoms: it's hard to soothe or settle your baby
they go red in the face
they bring their knees up to their tummy or arch their back
their tummy rumbles or they're very windy

name: Common cold
symptoms: pressure in your ears and face

name: Compartment syndrome
symptoms: pain in a muscle – this may feel like a burning pain or a deep ache (moving the body part can make the pain even worse)
swelling or bulging of the muscle
numbness, weakness or pins and needles
tightness or difficulty moving the affected body part

name: Confusion (sudden), see Sudden confusion (delirium)
symptoms: not be able to think or speak clearly or quickly
not know where they are (feel disorientated)
struggle to pay attention or remember things
see or hear things that are not there (hallucinations)

name: Conjunctivitis
symptoms: produce pus that sticks to lashes

name: Constipation
symptoms: you have not had a poo at least 3 times during the last week or you're pooing less often than usual
the poo is unusually large or small and is dry, hard or lumpy
you are straining or in pain when you have a poo
you feel like you haven't fully emptied your bowels

name: Coronary heart disease
symptoms: pain in your neck, shoulders, jaw or arms

name: Costochondritis
symptoms: you press the middle of your chest

name: Cradle cap
symptoms: patches of white or yellow greasy scales on the scalp and face that form a crust which might flake off
small, dry flakes of skin on the nappy area
1: Cradle cap on the scalp of a baby with white skin (thumbnail).1
2: Cradle cap on the scalp of a baby with medium brown skin (thumbnail).2
3: Cradle cap on the scalp of a baby with white skin (thumbnail).3
4: Cradle cap on the eyebrows of a baby with white skin (thumbnail).4

name: Craniosynostosis
symptoms: their head is long and narrow, like a rugby ball
their forehead is pointy or triangular
one side of their head is flattened or bulging out
the soft spot on the top of their head (fontanelle) disappears before they're 1 year old
breathing problems, like not being able to breathe through their mouth
dental problems, such as missing or crowded teeth

name: Croup
symptoms: a barking cough – this may sound like a seal (you can search online to hear examples)
a high pitched, rasping sound when breathing in

name: Cushing's syndrome
symptoms: increased fat on your chest and tummy, but slim arms and legs
a build-up of fat on the back of your neck and shoulders, known as a "buffalo hump"
weakness in your upper arms and thighs
a reduced sex drive (low libido) and fertility problems

name: Cyanosis, see Blue or grey skin or lips (cyanosis)
symptoms: skin (black or brown skin may turn grey - this may be easier to see on the palms of the hands, soles of the feet, lips, gums and inside the eyelids)

name: Cyclospora
symptoms: loss of appetite and weight loss

name: Cystitis
symptoms: pain, burning or stinging when you pee
needing to pee more often and urgently than usual
pee that's dark, cloudy or strong smelling
pain low down in your tummy
a high temperature – they feel hotter than usual if you touch their neck, back or tummy
changes in behaviour, such as acting confused or agitated (delirium)

name: Deafness, see Hearing loss
symptoms: difficulty hearing other people clearly and misunderstanding what they say, especially in noisy places
listening to music or watching TV with the volume higher than other people need
finding it hard to keep up with a conversation
feeling tired or stressed from having to concentrate while listening

name: Dehydration
symptoms: a dry mouth, lips and tongue
a sunken soft spot (fontanelle) on top of their head
few or no tears when they cry

name: Delirium, see Sudden confusion (delirium)
symptoms: not be able to think or speak clearly or quickly
not know where they are (feel disorientated)
struggle to pay attention or remember things
see or hear things that are not there (hallucinations)

name: Dementia (vascular), see Vascular dementia
symptoms: changes to your mood, personality or behaviour
symptoms of Alzheimer's disease, such as problems with memory and language (many people with vascular dementia also have Alzheimer's disease)

name: Dengue
symptoms: a blotchy rash made up of flat or slightly raised spots – this can affect large areas of your body

name: Dental abscess
symptoms: redness inside the mouth, or outside the mouth on the face or jaw
sensitivity to hot or cold food and drink in the affected area
a bad taste in your mouth
difficulty opening your mouth and chewing food

name: Detached retina (retinal detachment)
symptoms: floaters (dots and lines) or flashes of light in your eye
a dark "curtain" or shadow in your vision
changes to your eyesight, such as blurred vision

name: Diabetic ketoacidosis
symptoms: stomach pain, feeling sick or being sick
breath that smells fruity (like pear drop sweets or nail polish remover)
0.6 to 1.5mmol/L is slightly high – test again in 2 hours
1.6 to 3mmol/L means you're at risk of DKA and should speak to your diabetes care team for advice
over 3mmol/L is high and means you may have DKA and should call 999 or go to A&E

name: Dissociative disorders
symptoms: feeling disconnected from yourself and the world around you
forgetting about certain time periods, events and personal information
feeling uncertain about who you are
feeling little or no physical pain

name: Diverticular disease and diverticulitis
symptoms: pain in the lower left side of your tummy (abdomen) – a small number of people get pain on the right side
tummy pain that gets worse after you eat, and gets better after you poo or fart
bleeding or passing slime (mucus) from your bottom

name: Dizziness
symptoms: like you're spinning or things around you are spinning (vertigo)

name: Double vision
symptoms: narrowing or squinting their eyes to try to see better
closing 1 eye or covering 1 eye with their hand
turning their head in unusual ways (for example, tilting their head)
looking at you sideways instead of facing forward

name: DVT (deep vein thrombosis)
symptoms: throbbing pain in 1 leg (rarely both legs), usually in the calf or thigh, when walking or standing up
warm skin around the painful area
red or darkened skin around the painful area – this may be harder to see on brown or black skin
swollen veins that are hard or sore when you touch them

name: Dysarthria (difficulty speaking)
symptoms: difficulty moving your mouth, tongue or lips
difficulty controlling the volume of your voice, making you talk too loudly or quietly
a change in your voice, making it nasal, strained or monotone
hesitating a lot when talking, or speaking in short bursts instead of full sentences

name: Dysphagia (swallowing problems)
symptoms: coughing or choking when eating or drinking
bringing food back up, sometimes through the nose
a feeling that food is stuck in your throat or chest
a gurgly, wet-sounding voice when eating or drinking

name: Ear infections
symptoms: discharge running out of the ear
a feeling of pressure or fullness inside the ear
itching and irritation in and around the ear
scaly skin in and around the ear

name: Earache
symptoms: do not react to some sounds
have a temperature of 38C or above

name: Eardrum (burst), see Perforated eardrum
symptoms: injury (such as getting hit on your ear)
sudden change in air pressure (such as flying on a plane)
a ringing or buzzing sound in your ear (tinnitus)
clear fluid, blood or pus leaking from your ear

name: Earwax build-up
symptoms: earache or a feeling that your ears are blocked
ringing or buzzing in your ears (tinnitus)

name: Ebola virus disease
symptoms: yellowing of the skin and eyes
lots of bruises all over your body
bleeding from your ears, eyes, nose or mouth

name: Ectopic beats, see Heart palpitations
symptoms: irregular, with skipped or extra beats (ectopic beats)

name: Ehlers-Danlos syndromes
symptoms: an increased range of joint movement (joint hypermobility)
fragile skin that breaks or bruises easily

name: Encephalitis
symptoms: weakness or loss of movement in some parts of the body

name: Endometriosis
symptoms: pain in your lower tummy or back(pelvic pain)– usually worse during your period
period painthat stops you doing your normal activities
pain when peeing or pooing during your period
feeling sick, constipation, diarrhoea, or blood in your pee or poo during your period

name: Epididymitis
symptoms: sudden or gradual pain in 1 or both of your testicles (balls)
the bag of skin containing your testicles (scrotum) feeling tender, warm and swollen
a build-up of fluid around your testicle (a hydrocele) that feels like alump or swelling

name: Epilepsy
symptoms: uncontrollable jerking and shaking, called a "fit"
losing awareness and staring blankly into space
strange sensations, such as a "rising" feeling in the tummy, unusual smells or tastes, and a tingling feeling in your arms or legs

name: Erectile dysfunction (impotence)
symptoms: unable to keep an erection for long enough to have sex

name: Erythema nodosum
symptoms: have swollen, aching joints, particularly the knees, ankles and wrists

name: Erythromelalgia
symptoms: burning pain, which often starts as itching
redness – this can look different on brown or black skin

name: Excessive daytime sleepiness (hypersomnia)
symptoms: still sleep for long hours at night

name: Eye flashes, see Floaters and flashes in the eyes
symptoms: you've had them for a long time

name: Eye floaters, see Floaters and flashes in the eyes
symptoms: you've had them for a long time

name: Eye infection (herpes), see Herpes simplex eye infections
symptoms: blurred vision or other changes to your eyesight
blisters or a rash on your eyelid or the skin around your eye

name: Eyelid problems
symptoms: a lump that goes away by itself after several days or weeks
mildly itchy, flaky or sticky eyelids that clear up by themselves
swelling from a nearby insect bite, injury or operation that goes away after a week or so
twitching or blinking from time to time – often when you're tired
eyelids that droop (or get more "hooded") as you get older

name: Face blindness, see Prosopagnosia (face blindness)
symptoms: recognising characters and following plots in TV programmes or films
recognising other things, such as cars or animals

name: Febrile seizures
symptoms: become stiff and twitch, shake, or have jerking movements
not respond or look at you when you talk to them
be sleepy, irritable or confused for up to 1 hour afterwards

name: Fever in adults, see High temperature (fever) in adults
symptoms: your chest or back feel hotter than usual
you have other symptoms, such as shivering (chills), sweating or warm, red skin (this may be harder to see on black or brown skin)
a thermometer says your temperature is 38C or above

name: Fever in children, see High temperature (fever) in children
symptoms: feel hotter than usual when you touch their back or chest
have a seizure or fit, called afebrile seizure

name: Fibromyalgia
symptoms: difficulty getting to sleep or staying asleep, which can make you feel very tired (fatigue)
problems with mental processes (known as "fibro-fog"), such as difficulty concentrating or remembering things
irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), a digestive condition that causes stomach pain and bloating
feelings of frustration, worry or low mood

name: Fits (children with fever), see Febrile seizures
symptoms: become stiff and twitch, shake, or have jerking movements
not respond or look at you when you talk to them
be sleepy, irritable or confused for up to 1 hour afterwards

name: Flat feet
symptoms: do not usually cause any problems
should not stop you doing any activities, including sports
are rarely a sign of anything serious

name: Floaters and flashes in the eyes
symptoms: you've had them for a long time

name: Food allergy
symptoms: itchy skin or a raised rash (hives)
swelling of the lips, face and eyes (angioedema)
coughing, wheezing, breathlessness, noisy breathing or a hoarse voice
sneezing or an itchy, runny or blocked nose

name: Foreskin problems, see Tight foreskin (phimosis)
symptoms: pain when peeing or a weak flow of pee
bleeding or a thick discharge from under the foreskin or an unpleasant smell – these are signs of an infection (balanitis)
painful erections, which can make having sex difficult

name: Gallstones
symptoms: yellowing of the skin and eyes (jaundice)

name: Gastritis
symptoms: not feeling as hungry as usual

name: Gastro-oesophageal reflux disease (GORD), see Heartburn and acid reflux
symptoms: heartburn – a burning sensation in the middle of your chest
an unpleasant sour taste in your mouth, caused by stomach acid
a cough or hiccups that keep coming back

name: Gastroparesis
symptoms: feeling full sooner than usual – you may be unable to finish meals

name: Genital herpes
symptoms: small blisters that burst to leave red, open sores around your genitals, anus, thighs or bottom – the sores may be less red on brown or black skin
tingling, burning or itching around your genitals
discharge that is not usual for you

name: Genital warts
symptoms: around the vagina and on the penis
on the skin between the genitals and anus (perineum)
appear on their own or in a group (groups of warts can look like a cauliflower)
be white, red, skin-coloured, or darker than the surrounding skin
problems peeing (there may be blood in your pee, you may find it hard to pee, or you may stop and start a lot)

name: Giant cell arteritis, see Temporal arteritis
symptoms: pain or tenderness at the side of your head (temples) or on the scalp
jaw pain while eating or talking
vision problems, such asdouble visionor loss of vision in 1 or both eyes

name: Giardiasis
symptoms: smelly burps – they may smell like eggs

name: Glandular fever
symptoms: swollen glands, which may be in the neck, head, armpits, elbows, or groin
a rash, which may be harder to see on black or brown skin

name: Glue ear
symptoms: hearing sounds like ringing or buzzing (tinnitus)

name: Goitre
symptoms: a cough that does not go away
a hoarse voice or voice changes
feeling like something is stuck in your throat
a wheezing noise when you breathe
finding it hard to swallow or breathe

name: Gout
symptoms: sudden severe pain in a joint – usually your big toe, but it can be in other joints in your feet, ankles, hands, wrists, elbows or knees
hot, swollen, red skin over the affected joint – redness may be harder to see on black or brown skin.

name: Growing pains
symptoms: an aching or throbbing in both legs
in the muscles, not the joints
in the evening or night-time (and goes away by morning)

name: Gum disease
symptoms: your gums bleeding when you brush your teeth, floss or eat hard foods such as apples
your gums becoming swollen, red and sore
bad breath and a bad taste in the mouth
your teeth becoming loose or falling out

name: Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
symptoms: difficulty breathing – babies may make grunting noises
being sleepier than normal or difficult to wake
blue, grey, pale or blotchy skin, lips or tongue – on brown or black skin this may be noticeable under the nails or around the eyes
a rash that looks like small bruises or bleeding under the skin and does not disappear when you press a glass against it

name: Haemorrhoids, see Piles (haemorrhoids)
symptoms: bright red blood after you poo
feeling like you still need to poo after going to the toilet
mucus in your underwear or on toilet paper after wiping your bottom

name: Hallucinations and hearing voices
symptoms: hear sounds or voices that nobody else hears
see things that are not there like objects, shapes, people or lights
feel touch or movement in your body that is not real like bugs are crawling on your skin or your internal organs are moving around.
smell things that do not exist
taste things that only you feel are not pleasant or is strange
think that your body is moving like flying or floating when it is not

name: Hand, foot and mouth disease
symptoms: mouth ulcers, which can be painful
a raised rash of spots on the hands and feet, and sometimes the thighs and bottom
1: Hand, foot and mouth disease spots on white skin (thumbnail).1
2: Hand, foot and mouth disease spots and patches on medium brown skin (thumbnail).2
3: Hand, foot and mouth disease blister on white skin (thumbnail).3

name: Hay fever
symptoms: itchy throat, mouth, nose and ears
pain around the sides of your head and your forehead

name: Head lice and nits
symptoms: like something is moving in your hair

name: Headaches (tension-type), see Tension headaches
symptoms: pain on both sides of your head, face or neck
feeling like something is pressing on your head or being tightened around it
the affected area may feel tender and your head may hurt more when touched

name: Hearing loss
symptoms: difficulty hearing other people clearly and misunderstanding what they say, especially in noisy places
listening to music or watching TV with the volume higher than other people need
finding it hard to keep up with a conversation
feeling tired or stressed from having to concentrate while listening

name: Hearing voices, see Hallucinations and hearing voices
symptoms: hear sounds or voices that nobody else hears
see things that are not there like objects, shapes, people or lights
feel touch or movement in your body that is not real like bugs are crawling on your skin or your internal organs are moving around.
smell things that do not exist
taste things that only you feel are not pleasant or is strange
think that your body is moving like flying or floating when it is not

name: Heart attack
symptoms: chest pain – a feeling of pressure, heaviness, tightness or squeezing across your chest
pain in other parts of the body – it can feel as if the pain is spreading from your chest to your arms (usually the left arm, but it can affect both arms), jaw, neck, back and tummy
an overwhelming feeling of anxiety (similar to a panic attack)

name: Heart disease (coronary), see Coronary heart disease
symptoms: pain in your neck, shoulders, jaw or arms

name: Heart failure
symptoms: feeling tired most of the time and finding exercise exhausting

name: Heart palpitations
symptoms: irregular, with skipped or extra beats (ectopic beats)

name: Heartburn and acid reflux
symptoms: heartburn – a burning sensation in the middle of your chest
an unpleasant sour taste in your mouth, caused by stomach acid
a cough or hiccups that keep coming back

name: Heat exhaustion and heatstroke
symptoms: excessive sweating and skin becoming pale and clammy or getting aheat rash, but a change in skin colour can be harder to see on brown and black skin
cramps in the arms, legs and stomach

name: Heavy periods
symptoms: need to change your pad or tampon every 1 to 2 hours, or empty your menstrual cup more often than is recommended
need to use 2 types of sanitary product together, such as a pad and a tampon
have periods lasting more than 7 days
pass blood clots larger than about 2.5cm (the size of a 10p coin)
bleed through to your clothes or bedding
avoid daily activities, like exercise, or take time off work because of your periods
feel tired or short of breath a lot

name: Hepatitis A
symptoms: flu-like symptoms, such as tiredness, headache, and muscle pains
pale yellow or pale grey poo
itchy skin – you may also have a raised rash (hives)
yellowing of the skin and the whites of the eyes (jaundice)

name: Hepatitis B
symptoms: patches of raised skin that may be itchy (hives)
yellowing of the skin and whites of the eyes (jaundice)

name: Hepatitis C
symptoms: flu-like symptoms, such as muscle aches and a high temperature (fever)

name: Hernia (hiatus), see Hiatus hernia
symptoms: have a painful burning feeling in your chest, often after eating (heartburn)
bring up small amounts of food or bitter-tasting fluids (acid reflux)
have difficulty or pain when swallowing

name: Herpes (genital), see Genital herpes
symptoms: small blisters that burst to leave red, open sores around your genitals, anus, thighs or bottom – the sores may be less red on brown or black skin
tingling, burning or itching around your genitals
discharge that is not usual for you

name: Herpes simplex eye infections
symptoms: blurred vision or other changes to your eyesight
blisters or a rash on your eyelid or the skin around your eye

name: Herpetic whitlow (whitlow finger)
symptoms: swelling and pain in your finger
blisters or sores on your finger
skin becoming red or darker than your usual skin tone
feeling generally unwell and having a high temperature

name: Hiatus hernia
symptoms: have a painful burning feeling in your chest, often after eating (heartburn)
bring up small amounts of food or bitter-tasting fluids (acid reflux)
have difficulty or pain when swallowing

name: Hib, see Haemophilus influenzae type b (Hib)
symptoms: difficulty breathing – babies may make grunting noises
being sleepier than normal or difficult to wake
blue, grey, pale or blotchy skin, lips or tongue – on brown or black skin this may be noticeable under the nails or around the eyes
a rash that looks like small bruises or bleeding under the skin and does not disappear when you press a glass against it

name: High temperature (fever) in adults
symptoms: your chest or back feel hotter than usual
you have other symptoms, such as shivering (chills), sweating or warm, red skin (this may be harder to see on black or brown skin)
a thermometer says your temperature is 38C or above

name: High temperature (fever) in children
symptoms: feel hotter than usual when you touch their back or chest
have a seizure or fit, called afebrile seizure

name: Hives
symptoms: be raised bumps or patches in many shapes and sizes
be on 1 area or spread across the body
look pink or red when affecting someone with white skin; the colour of the rash can be harder to see on brown and black skin
3: Hives rash on light brown skin (thumbnail).3
4: Hives rash on light brown skin (thumbnail).4
5: Hives rash on light brown skin (thumbnail).5
6: Dark brown skin with hives rash (thumbnail).6

name: Hypersomnia, see Excessive daytime sleepiness (hypersomnia)
symptoms: still sleep for long hours at night

name: Hypoglycaemia, see Low blood sugar (hypoglycaemia)
symptoms: changes in your vision such as blurred vision

name: Hypothermia
symptoms: pale, cold and dry skin – skin and lips may turn blue or grey (on black or brown skin this may be easier to see on the palms of the hands or the soles of the feet)
unusually quiet and sleepy and may refuse to feed

name: IBD, see Inflammatory bowel disease
symptoms: diarrhoea that lasts longer than 4 weeks
blood or mucus (clear slime) in your poo

name: Ichthyosis
symptoms: a thin yellow, shiny layer on the skin at birth that dries out and flakes off
tight skin which can make moving the affected area painful
sweating less, which can lead to overheating

name: Impetigo
symptoms: look a bit like cornflakes stuck to your skin
spread to other parts of your body

name: Impotence, see Erectile dysfunction (impotence)
symptoms: unable to keep an erection for long enough to have sex

name: Indigestion
symptoms: heartburn – a painful burning feeling in the chest, often after eating
bringing up food or bitter-tasting fluids into your mouth

name: Infected piercings
symptoms: be tender, itchy, and the surrounding area may look slightly red on white skin, or a little darker than usual on dark skin
produce a pale fluid that forms a crust
the area around it is swollen, painful, hot, very red or dark (depending on your skin colour)
there's blood or pus coming out of it – pus can be white, green or yellow
you feel hot or shivery or generally unwell

name: Inflammatory bowel disease
symptoms: diarrhoea that lasts longer than 4 weeks
blood or mucus (clear slime) in your poo

name: Insect bites and stings
symptoms: pain where you were bitten or stung
a small, swollen lump on the skin

name: Insomnia
symptoms: find it hard to go to sleep
wake up several times during the night
wake up early and cannot go back to sleep
still feel tired after waking up
find it hard to nap during the day even though you're tired
feel tired and irritable during the day
find it difficult to concentrate during the day because you're tired

name: Interstitial cystitis, see Bladder pain syndrome (interstitial cystitis)
symptoms: intensepelvic pain(felt over your lower tummy)
needing to pee more often than usual
pain in your lower tummy when your bladder is filling up, which is relieved when you pee
waking up several times during the night to pee

name: Iron deficiency anaemia
symptoms: hearing ringing, buzzing or hissing noises inside your head (tinnitus)
hair loss – you notice more hair coming out when brushing or washing it
wanting to eat non-food items, such as paper or ice (pica)
painful open sores (ulcers) in the corners of your mouth

name: Japanese encephalitis
symptoms: not being able to feel or move parts of your body (paralysis)

name: Jaw pain, see Temporomandibular disorder (TMD)
symptoms: pain around your jaw, ear and temple
clicking, popping or grinding noises when you move your jaw
your jaw locking when you open your mouth

name: Jet lag
symptoms: difficulty sleeping at bedtime and waking up in the morning
difficulty staying awake during the day

name: Joint hypermobility syndrome
symptoms: often get tired, even after rest
keep getting pain and stiffness in your joints or muscles

name: Kidney infection
symptoms: needing to pee suddenly or more often than usual
pain or a burning sensation when peeing

name: Knee cartilage damage, see Meniscus tear (knee cartilage damage)
symptoms: stiffness or swelling around your knee – the swelling may not start for a few hours or days
difficulty bending, straightening or moving your knee
your knee giving way when you try to stand
a crunching or clicking feeling when you move your knee

name: Labyrinthitis and vestibular neuritis
symptoms: dizzinessor feeling that everything around you is spinning (vertigo)
feeling unsteady and off balance – you might find it difficult to stay upright or walk in a straight line

name: Lactose intolerance
symptoms: baked foods like bread, crackers, cakes, biscuits, and pastry

name: Laryngitis
symptoms: an irritating cough that does not go away
always needing to clear your throat
have a temperature of 38C or above
be off their food or drink
have difficulty breathing (but this is rare)

name: Lazy eye
symptoms: shutting 1 eye or squinting when looking at things
not being able to follow an object or person with your eyes
tilting your head when looking at something
having tired eyes and rubbing your eyes a lot
tripping or falling over a lot

name: Leg cramps
symptoms: calf muscle, below the knee at the back of the leg
muscles in the feet or the thighs (less often)

name: Legionnaires' disease
symptoms: chest pain or discomfort, particularly when breathing or coughing

name: Leptospirosis (Weil's disease)
symptoms: redness in the white part of your eyes
yellowing of the skin (which may be harder to see on black or brown skin) or white part of the eyes (jaundice)

name: Lichen planus
symptoms: clusters of shiny, raised, purple-red blotches on your arms, legs or body (you may see fine white lines on the blotches) – the rash may be harder to see on black or brown skin
white patches on your gums, tongue or the insides of your cheeks
burning and stinging in your mouth, especially when you eat or drink
bald patches appearing on your scalp
sore red patches on your vulva
rough, thinning nails with grooves on
ring-shaped purple or white patches on your penis

name: Lichen sclerosus
symptoms: easily damaged – they may bleed or hurt if rubbed or scratched
area around the opening to the vagina (vulva) and anus
foreskin and end of the penis

name: Lipoma
symptoms: can be anything from the size of a pea to a few centimetres across
may move slightly under your skin if you press them
can appear anywhere on your body

name: Liver disease
symptoms: feeling very tired and weak all the time
loss of appetite – which may lead to weight loss
yellow skin and whites of the eyes (jaundice)

name: Liver disease (alcohol-related), see Alcohol-related liver disease
symptoms: yellowing of the whites of the eyes or skin (jaundice)
swelling in the ankles and tummy
vomiting blood or passing blood in your stools

name: Long-sightedness
symptoms: finding it hard to see nearby things, for example, words and pictures in books or on screens may look fuzzy
being able to see things more clearly when you move them further away from your eyes
tired eyes after tasks that involve looking at something closely, like reading or working at a computer

name: Low blood sugar (hypoglycaemia)
symptoms: changes in your vision such as blurred vision

name: Low white blood cell count
symptoms: mouth sores that keep coming back

name: Lumps
symptoms: be soft or hard to touch
be very small or up to the size of a golf ball
be a lump under the skin or a growth that hangs off your skin

name: Lupus
symptoms: extreme tiredness that will not go away no matter how much you rest
rashes that usually come on after being in the sun – the rash is often over the nose and cheeks
swollen glands, usually in the neck, armpits or groin
changes in the colour of your fingers and toes when you're cold, anxious or stressed (Raynaud's)
you often get symptoms of lupus

name: Lyme disease
symptoms: a high temperature, or feeling hot and shivery

name: Malaria
symptoms: a high temperature, sweats and chills
feeling very tired and sleepy (especially in children)
feeling and being sick, tummy pain and diarrhoea
yellow skin or whites of the eyes
a sore throat, cough and difficulty breathing

name: Mastitis
symptoms: a swollen area on your breast that may feel hot and painful to touch – the area may become red but this can be harder to see if you have black or brown skin
a wedge-shapedbreast lumpor a hard area on your breast
a burning pain in your breast that might be constant or only when you breastfeed
nipple discharge, which may be white or contain streaks of blood

name: Mastoiditis
symptoms: pain, soreness or tenderness behind the ear
redness behind the ear (this can be harder to see on brown or black skin)
swelling behind the ear, which can cause it to stick out

name: Meningitis
symptoms: a rash that does not fade when a glass is rolled over it (but a rash will not always develop)

name: Meniscus tear (knee cartilage damage)
symptoms: stiffness or swelling around your knee – the swelling may not start for a few hours or days
difficulty bending, straightening or moving your knee
your knee giving way when you try to stand
a crunching or clicking feeling when you move your knee

name: Menstrual pain, see Period pain
symptoms: you have pain in your tummy at the start of your period, or several days before your period
you have painful cramps in your tummy that spread to your back and thighs
you have a sharp pain or a dull ache in your tummy

name: Migraine
symptoms: feeling very tired and yawning a lot
craving certain foods or feeling thirsty
problems with your sight, such as seeing zigzag lines or flashing lights
numbness or a tingling that feels like pins and needles

name: Moles
symptoms: babies to be born with moles
new moles to appear – especially in children and teenagers
moles to fade or disappear as you get older
moles to get slightly darker during pregnancy

name: Motor neurone disease
symptoms: weakness in your ankle or leg – you might trip, or find it harder to climb stairs
slurred speech, which may develop into difficulty swallowing some foods
a weak grip – you might drop things, or find it hard to open jars or do up buttons
weight loss – your arms or leg muscles may have become thinner over time
difficulty stopping yourself from crying or laughing in inappropriate situations

name: Mouth thrush, see Oral thrush (mouth thrush)
symptoms: cracks at the corners of the mouth
an unpleasant taste in the mouth
pain inside the mouth (for example, a sore tongue or sore gums)

name: MRSA
symptoms: feels warm when you touch it
looks red – though this may be harder to see on brown or black skin

name: Mucositis
symptoms: a sore mouth, which can make eating and drinking painful
bleeding from your gut (you may have blood in your poo)

name: Multiple sclerosis
symptoms: vision problems, such as blurred vision
numbness or tingling in different parts of the body
problems with thinking, learning and planning

name: Myalgic encephalomyelitis or chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS)
symptoms: feeling extremely tired all the time – you may find it very hard to do daily activities
still feeling tired after resting or sleeping
taking a long time to recover after physical activity
problems sleeping, such as waking up often during the night
problems with thinking, memory and concentration

name: Myopia, see Short-sightedness (myopia)
symptoms: difficulty reading words from a distance, such as reading the whiteboard at school
sitting close to the TV or computer, or holding a mobile phone or tablet close to the face

name: Myositis
symptoms: lift objects, such as a cup of tea
a patchy, red rash, usually on the eyelids, face, neck and the backs of the hands – this can look different on brown or black skin

name: Ménière's disease
symptoms: feeling like you or everything around you is spinning (vertigo)
ringing or buzzing sounds in 1 or both ears (tinnitus)
feeling pressure, discomfort or pain deep inside your ear

name: Nail problems
symptoms: become thicker or break more easily (brittle) as you get older
become harder, softer or more brittle during pregnancy (they should be healthier within 6 months of having a baby)
change colour, become loose and eventually fall off after an injury

name: Nappy rash
symptoms: red or raw patches on your baby’s bottom or the whole nappy area
skin that looks sore and feels hot to touch
your baby seeming uncomfortable or distressed
spots, pimples, or blisters on bottom (spots can appear red or brown, but may be less noticeable on brown and black skin)

name: Nasal and sinus cancer
symptoms: a blocked nose that does not go away and usually only affects 1 side
mucus running from your nose – this can be bloody
mucus draining into the back of your nose and throat
pain or numbness in the face, particularly in the upper cheek, that does not go away
partial loss of vision ordouble vision
awatering eyethat does not go away
a persistent lump or growth on your face, nose or roof of your mouth

name: Nasal polyps
symptoms: a feeling that mucus is slowly dripping down the back of your throat (postnasal drip)
a reduced sense of smell or taste

name: Necrotising fasciitis
symptoms: intense pain or loss of feeling near to a cut or wound – the pain may seem much worse than you would usually expect from a cut or wound
swelling of the skin around the affected area
flu-like symptoms, such as a high temperature, headache and tiredness
black, purple or grey blotches and blisters on the skin (these may be less obvious on black or brown skin)

name: Non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD)
symptoms: a dull or aching pain in the top right of the tummy (over the lower right side of the ribs)

name: Non-gonococcal urethritis, see Urethritis
symptoms: pain or a burning feeling when you pee
white or cloudy discharge from the vagina or penis
an irritated or sore tip of the penis

name: Nose cancer, see Nasal and sinus cancer
symptoms: a blocked nose that does not go away and usually only affects 1 side
mucus running from your nose – this can be bloody
mucus draining into the back of your nose and throat
pain or numbness in the face, particularly in the upper cheek, that does not go away
partial loss of vision ordouble vision
awatering eyethat does not go away
a persistent lump or growth on your face, nose or roof of your mouth

name: Obesity
symptoms: below 18.5 – you're in the underweight range
18.5 to 24.9 – you're in the healthy weight range
25 to 29.9 – you're in the overweight range
30 to 39.9 – you're in the obese range
40 or above – you're in the severely obese range
23 to 27.4 – you're in the overweight range
27.5 or above – you're in the obese range

name: Obstructive sleep apnoea, see Sleep apnoea
symptoms: making gasping, snorting or choking noises
have a headache when you wake up

name: Oral thrush (mouth thrush)
symptoms: cracks at the corners of the mouth
an unpleasant taste in the mouth
pain inside the mouth (for example, a sore tongue or sore gums)

name: Orf
symptoms: swollen glands on the inside of your elbow or under your arm

name: Osteomyelitis
symptoms: a feeling of warmth on the affected area
redness of the skin in the affected area, which may be harder to see on black or brown skin

name: Osteophyte (bone spur)
symptoms: pins and needles, numbness or weakness in the arms and legs
lumps on joints like the fingers, big toe, heel and ankle

name: Otosclerosis
symptoms: gradual hearing loss in 1 or both ears, often over several years
hearing ringing, buzzing or other noises in 1 or both ears (tinnitus)

name: Ovarian cyst
symptoms: pelvic pain– this can range from a dull, heavy sensation to a sudden, severe and sharp pain
heavy periods,irregular periodsor lighter periods than normal
feeling very full after only eating a little
difficulty getting pregnant – although fertility is usually unaffected by ovarian cysts

name: Ovulation pain
symptoms: feels like a dull pain or sharp sudden twinges
lasts from a few minutes to 1 or 2 days
happens about 14 days before a period
only affects 1 side of your tummy at a time
switches sides each time, depending on which ovary releases an egg

name: Painful bladder syndrome, see Bladder pain syndrome (interstitial cystitis)
symptoms: intensepelvic pain(felt over your lower tummy)
needing to pee more often than usual
pain in your lower tummy when your bladder is filling up, which is relieved when you pee
waking up several times during the night to pee

name: Painful periods, see Period pain
symptoms: you have pain in your tummy at the start of your period, or several days before your period
you have painful cramps in your tummy that spread to your back and thighs
you have a sharp pain or a dull ache in your tummy

name: Palpitations, see Heart palpitations
symptoms: irregular, with skipped or extra beats (ectopic beats)

name: Panic disorder
symptoms: a feeling of dread or a fear of dying
feeling like you're not connected to your body

name: Paralysis
symptoms: you cannot move some or all of your face or body
your face or body is weak or floppy
your face or body is numb, painful or tingles all the time
your face or body is stiff with muscle spasms and twitches

name: Parkinson's disease
symptoms: involuntary shaking of particular parts of the body(tremor)
balance problems (this may increase the chances of afall)

name: Pelvic inflammatory disease
symptoms: pain around the pelvis or lower tummy
discomfort or pain during sex that's felt deep inside the pelvis
bleeding between periods and after sex
unusualvaginal discharge, especially if it's yellow, green or smelly

name: Pelvic organ prolapse
symptoms: a feeling of heaviness around your lower tummy and genitals
a dragging discomfort inside your vagina
feeling like there's something coming down into your vagina – it may feel like sitting on a small ball
feeling or seeing a bulge or lump in or coming out of your vagina

problems peeing – such as feeling like your bladder is not emptying fully, needing to go to the toilet more often, or leaking a small amount of pee when you cough, sneeze or exercise(stress incontinence)

name: Pelvic pain
symptoms: a sharp, stabbing or burning pain that happens suddenly
a pain that comes on slowly but does not go away
a dull or heavy ache, or feeling of pressure
a cramping or throbbing pain, which may come and go
pain only when you’re doing something, like exercising, having sex, or peeing

name: Perforated eardrum
symptoms: injury (such as getting hit on your ear)
sudden change in air pressure (such as flying on a plane)
a ringing or buzzing sound in your ear (tinnitus)
clear fluid, blood or pus leaking from your ear

name: Pericarditis
symptoms: spreads to your shoulders, arms or tummy
gets worse when you breathe in deeply, swallow, cough or lie down (especially when you lie down on your left side)
gets better when you lean forward

name: Period pain
symptoms: you have pain in your tummy at the start of your period, or several days before your period
you have painful cramps in your tummy that spread to your back and thighs
you have a sharp pain or a dull ache in your tummy

name: Periods (heavy), see Heavy periods
symptoms: need to change your pad or tampon every 1 to 2 hours, or empty your menstrual cup more often than is recommended
need to use 2 types of sanitary product together, such as a pad and a tampon
have periods lasting more than 7 days
pass blood clots larger than about 2.5cm (the size of a 10p coin)
bleed through to your clothes or bedding
avoid daily activities, like exercise, or take time off work because of your periods
feel tired or short of breath a lot

name: Peripheral neuropathy
symptoms: numbness and tingling in the feet or hands
burning, stabbing or shooting pain in affected areas
muscle weakness, especially in the feet

name: Peritonitis
symptoms: a very high temperature, or feeling hot and shivery
a rapid heartbeat (your heart is beating more quickly than normal)
not being able to pee or peeing much less than normal
a lack of appetite and feel or be sick

name: Phimosis, see Tight foreskin (phimosis)
symptoms: pain when peeing or a weak flow of pee
bleeding or a thick discharge from under the foreskin or an unpleasant smell – these are signs of an infection (balanitis)
painful erections, which can make having sex difficult

name: Phlebitis (superficial thrombophlebitis)
symptoms: pain, tenderness or swelling in the affected area
warm and itchy skin over the affected area
changes to the colour and texture of the surrounding skin – for example, the skin may be red and it may be thick and hard

name: Piles (haemorrhoids)
symptoms: bright red blood after you poo
feeling like you still need to poo after going to the toilet
mucus in your underwear or on toilet paper after wiping your bottom

name: Plantar fasciitis
symptoms: the pain is much worse when you start walking after sleeping or resting
the pain feels better during exercise, but returns after resting
it's difficult to raise your toes off the floor

name: PMS (premenstrual syndrome)
symptoms: changes in appetite and sex drive

name: Pneumonia
symptoms: a cough – you may cough up yellow or green mucus (phlegm)
making wheezing noises when you breathe – babies may also make grunting noises
feeling confused – this is common in older people

name: Polycystic ovary syndrome
symptoms: irregular periods orno periods at all
difficulty getting pregnant as a result of irregular ovulation or no ovulation
excessive hair growth (hirsutism)– usually on the face, chest, back or buttocks
thinning hair andhair lossfrom the head

name: Polymorphic light eruption
symptoms: you may get crops of 2mm to 5mm raised, pink or red spots, but redness may be harder to see on brown and black skin
some people get blisters that turn into larger, dry patches – it looks a bit likeeczema
less commonly, the patches look like a target or "bulls-eye" (it looks a bit likeerythema multiforme)

name: Postural tachycardia syndrome (PoTS)
symptoms: problems with your stomach or digestion, such as feeling sick, being sick, diarrhoea, constipation, bloating and tummy pain
headaches and problems with your sight, such as blurred vision or tunnel vision
your hands and feet looking purple – this may be more difficult to see if you have brown or black skin
weakness and extreme tiredness (fatigue), not being able to do much exercise, and sleeping badly
problems with thinking, memory and concentration (brain fog)

name: Pre-eclampsia
symptoms: vision problems, such as blurring or flashing
sudden swelling of the face, hands or feet

name: Pressure ulcers (pressure sores)
symptoms: discoloured patches of skin that do not change colour when pressed – the patches are usually red on white skin, or purple or blue on black or brown skin
a patch of skin that feels warm, spongy or hard
pain or itchiness in the affected area of skin

name: Prickly heat, see Heat rash (prickly heat)
Prolapse (pelvic organ), see Pelvic organ prolapse
symptoms: a feeling of heaviness around your lower tummy and genitals
a dragging discomfort inside your vagina
feeling like there's something coming down into your vagina – it may feel like sitting on a small ball
feeling or seeing a bulge or lump in or coming out of your vagina

problems peeing – such as feeling like your bladder is not emptying fully, needing to go to the toilet more often, or leaking a small amount of pee when you cough, sneeze or exercise(stress incontinence)

name: Prosopagnosia (face blindness)
symptoms: recognising characters and following plots in TV programmes or films
recognising other things, such as cars or animals

name: Prostate cancer
symptoms: a feeling that your bladder has not fully emptied

name: Prostate enlargement, see Benign prostate enlargement
Prostatitis
symptoms: pain when peeing, which may feel like stinging or burning
difficulty peeing or straining to pee
needing to pee more often than usual
pain in your penis, scrotum, testicles or bottom

name: Psoriatic arthritis
symptoms: pain, swelling and stiffness in 1 or more joints
your nails changing from their usual colour, or tiny dents or pits developing in your nails

name: Pubic lice
symptoms: itching, which is usually worse at night
small red or blue spots on your skin (lice bites)
white/yellow dots attached to your hair (lice eggs)
dark red or brown spots in your underwear (lice poo)
crusted or sticky eyelashes, if they're affected

name: Pudendal neuralgia
symptoms: genitals (your vagina, vulva and clitoris or penis and scrotum)
perineum (the area between your genitals and anus)
a feeling of swelling or fullness in your anus or vagina

name: Pulmonary embolism
symptoms: difficulty breathing that comes on suddenly
chest pain that's worse when you breathe in

name: Quinsy, see Tonsillitis
symptoms: swollen, painful glands in your neck (feels like a lump on the side of your neck)
pus-filled spots or white patches on your tonsils

name: Rabies
symptoms: numbness or tingling where you were bitten or scratched
seeing things that are not there (hallucinations)

name: Rectal bleeding, see Bleeding from the bottom (rectal bleeding)
symptoms: red streaks on the outside of your poo
pink water in the toilet bowl
blood in your poo or bloody diarrhoea
very dark poo (this can be blood mixed in poo)

name: Reflux in babies
symptoms: bringing up milk or being sick during or shortly after feeding
swallowing or gulping after burping or feeding
not gaining weight as they're not keeping enough food down

name: Repetitive strain injury (RSI)
symptoms: pain, which may feel like burning, aching or throbbing

name: Retinal detachment, see Detached retina (retinal detachment)
symptoms: floaters (dots and lines) or flashes of light in your eye
a dark "curtain" or shadow in your vision
changes to your eyesight, such as blurred vision

name: Retinal migraine
symptoms: vision loss – this usually lasts around 10 to 20 minutes but can sometimes last up to 1 hour
a blind spot in your vision
a headache – you may get this at the same time as the eye symptoms or shortly afterwards
other eye symptoms, such as blurred vision and seeing flashing lights, zigzag patterns or coloured spots or lines

name: Reye's syndrome
symptoms: have changes in their behaviour, such as being irritable or aggressive
breathe quickly and have a fast heart rate

name: Rhinitis (allergic), see Allergic rhinitis
symptoms: the roof of your mouth being itchy

name: Rosacea
symptoms: redness (blushing) across your nose, cheeks, forehead, chin, neck and chest that comes and goes, usually lasting for a few minutes each time – your face may also feel warm, hot or painful
a burning or stinging feeling when using water or skincare products
sore eyelids or crusts around roots of eyelashes – this could beblepharitis
thickened skin, mainly on the nose (usually appears after many years)
contact dermatitis, seborrhoeic dermatitis and other types of dermatitis

name: Roseola
symptoms: cold-like symptoms such as a sore throat, runny nose and a cough
swollen eyelids and swollen glands in their neck
is made up of pinkish-red spots, patches or bumps
may be harder to see on brown or black skin
starts on the chest, tummy and back, before spreading to the face, neck and arms
is not usually itchy or uncomfortable
normally fades and disappears within 2 days

name: Salivary gland stones
symptoms: dull pain in your mouth that comes and goes
swelling in your mouth that flares up from time to time
an infection around the stone – signs of infection include pain, redness and a high temperature

name: Sciatica
symptoms: painful – the pain may be stabbing, burning or shooting

name: Scurvy
symptoms: feeling very tired and weak all the time
feeling irritable and sad all the time
swollen, bleeding gums (sometimes teeth can fall out)
developing red or blue spots on the skin, usually on the legs and feet, although this may be less noticeable on brown or black skin

name: Seizures (children with fever), see Febrile seizures
symptoms: become stiff and twitch, shake, or have jerking movements
not respond or look at you when you talk to them
be sleepy, irritable or confused for up to 1 hour afterwards

name: Sepsis
symptoms: blue, grey, pale or blotchy skin, lips or tongue – on brown or black skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of the hands or soles of the feet
a rash that does not fade when you roll a glass over it, the same asmeningitis
difficulty breathing (you may notice grunting noises or their stomach sucking under their ribcage), breathlessness or breathing very fast
a weak, high-pitched cry that's not like their normal cry
not responding like they normally do, or not interested in feeding or normal activities
being sleepier than normal or difficult to wake
acting confused, slurred speech or not making sense
blue, grey, pale or blotchy skin, lips or tongue – on brown or black skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of the hands or soles of the feet
a rash that does not fade when you roll a glass over it, the same asmeningitis
difficulty breathing, breathlessness or breathing very fast
feels very unwell or like there's something seriously wrong
has not had a pee all day (for adults and older children) or in the last 12 hours (for babies and young children)
keeps vomiting and cannot keep any food or milk down (for babies and young children)
has swelling or pain around a cut or wound
has a very high or low temperature, feels hot or cold to the touch, or is shivering

name: Septicaemia, see Sepsis
symptoms: blue, grey, pale or blotchy skin, lips or tongue – on brown or black skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of the hands or soles of the feet
a rash that does not fade when you roll a glass over it, the same asmeningitis
difficulty breathing (you may notice grunting noises or their stomach sucking under their ribcage), breathlessness or breathing very fast
a weak, high-pitched cry that's not like their normal cry
not responding like they normally do, or not interested in feeding or normal activities
being sleepier than normal or difficult to wake
acting confused, slurred speech or not making sense
blue, grey, pale or blotchy skin, lips or tongue – on brown or black skin, this may be easier to see on the palms of the hands or soles of the feet
a rash that does not fade when you roll a glass over it, the same asmeningitis
difficulty breathing, breathlessness or breathing very fast
feels very unwell or like there's something seriously wrong
has not had a pee all day (for adults and older children) or in the last 12 hours (for babies and young children)
keeps vomiting and cannot keep any food or milk down (for babies and young children)
has swelling or pain around a cut or wound
has a very high or low temperature, feels hot or cold to the touch, or is shivering

name: Shingles
symptoms: a tingling or painful feeling in an area of skin
a headache or feeling generally unwell

name: Short-sightedness (myopia)
symptoms: difficulty reading words from a distance, such as reading the whiteboard at school
sitting close to the TV or computer, or holding a mobile phone or tablet close to the face

name: Shoulder impingement
symptoms: pain in the top and outer side of your shoulder
pain that's worse when you lift your arm, especially when you lift it above your head
pain or aching at night, which can affect your sleep

name: Sinus cancer, see Nasal and sinus cancer
symptoms: a blocked nose that does not go away and usually only affects 1 side
mucus running from your nose – this can be bloody
mucus draining into the back of your nose and throat
pain or numbness in the face, particularly in the upper cheek, that does not go away
partial loss of vision ordouble vision
awatering eyethat does not go away
a persistent lump or growth on your face, nose or roof of your mouth

name: Sinusitis (sinus infection)
symptoms: pain, swelling and tenderness around your cheeks, eyes or forehead
green or yellow mucus from your nose
a feeling of pressure in the ears

name: Sinusitis, see Sinusitis (sinus infection)
symptoms: pain, swelling and tenderness around your cheeks, eyes or forehead
green or yellow mucus from your nose
a feeling of pressure in the ears

name: Sjögren's syndrome
symptoms: swelling between the jaw and ears (swollen salivary glands)
rashes (especially after being in the sun)

name: Skin cyst
symptoms: are round lumps just underneath the skin
sometimes have a small, dark spot in the middle
grow slowly and vary in size from smaller than a pea to several centimetres across
can get sore or red if they get infected – the redness may be harder to see on black or brown skin

name: Skin picking disorder
symptoms: cause cuts, bleeding or bruising by picking your skin
pick moles, freckles, spots or scars to try to "smooth" or "perfect" them
do not always realise you're picking your skin or do it when you're asleep
pick your skin when you feel anxious or stressed

name: Skin tags
symptoms: Wartsare more commonly found on the hands and feet. Most warts are firm, raised off the skin and have a rough surface.

Molesare usually found on areas of skin exposed to the sun. They are usually a different colour to the rest of your skin and can be pink, light brown, brown or darker brown depending on the colour of your skin tone. Moles are usually flat and round or oval.

name: Slapped cheek syndrome
symptoms: a runny nose and sore throat

name: Sleep apnoea
symptoms: making gasping, snorting or choking noises
have a headache when you wake up

name: Sleep paralysis
symptoms: awake but cannot move, speak or open your eyes
like someone is in your room
like something is pushing you down

name: Slipped disc
symptoms: numbness or tingling in your shoulders, back, arms, hands, legs or feet
problems bending or straightening your back
pain in the buttocks, hips or legs if the disc is pressing on the sciatic nerve (sciatica)

name: Social anxiety (social phobia)
symptoms: worry about everyday activities, such as meeting strangers, starting conversations, speaking on the phone, working or shopping
avoid or worry a lot about social activities, such as group conversations, eating with company and parties
always worry about doing something you think is embarrassing, such asblushing, sweating or appearing incompetent
find it difficult to do things when others are watching – you may feel like you're being watched and judged all the time
fear being criticised, avoid eye contact or havelow self-esteem
often have symptoms like feeling sick, sweating, trembling or apounding heartbeat (palpitations)
havepanic attacks, where you have an overwhelming sense of fear and anxiety, usually only for a few minutes

name: Solar keratoses, see Actinic keratoses (solar keratoses)
symptoms: can feel dry, rough and scaly, or like sandpaper
are usually between 1cm and 2cm in size
can be the same colour as your skin, or range from pink to red to brown

name: Sore throat
symptoms: a painful throat, especially when swallowing
redness in the back of your mouth

name: Spondylolisthesis
symptoms: pain in your lower back, often worse when standing or walking and relieved when sitting or bending forward
pain spreading to your bottom or thighs
tight hamstrings (the muscles in the back of your thighs)
pain, numbness or tingling spreading from your lower back down 1 leg (sciatica)

name: Sprains and strains
symptoms: you have pain, tenderness or weakness – often around your ankle, foot, wrist, thumb, knee, leg or back
the injured area is swollen or bruised
you cannot put weight on the injury or use it normally
you have muscle spasms or cramping – where your muscles painfully tighten on their own

name: Stevens-Johnson syndrome
symptoms: on your lips and in your mouth and throat – this can make swallowing painful
in the tube that carries pee out of your body – this can cause pain when peeing
on your eyes – this can cause eye pain, pain when looking at bright lights and problems with your sight

name: Sting or bite (insect), see Insect bites and stings
symptoms: pain where you were bitten or stung
a small, swollen lump on the skin

name: Strep A
symptoms: flu-like symptoms, such as a high temperature, swollen glands or an aching body
a rash that feels rough, like sandpaper (scarlet fever)

name: Stroke
symptoms: Face– the face may have dropped on 1 side, the person may not be able to smile, or their mouth or eye may have dropped.
Arms– the person with suspected stroke may not be able to lift both arms and keep them there because of weakness or numbness in 1 arm.
Speech– their speech may be slurred or garbled, or the person may not be able to talk at all despite appearing to be awake; they may also have problems understanding what you're saying to them.
Time– it's time to dial 999 immediately if you see any of these signs or symptoms.

name: Stye
symptoms: there's no lump – if your eye or eyelid is swollen, red and watery it's more likely to beconjunctivitisorblepharitis
the lump is hard but not very painful – it's more likely to be achalazion

name: Sudden confusion (delirium)
symptoms: not be able to think or speak clearly or quickly
not know where they are (feel disorientated)
struggle to pay attention or remember things
see or hear things that are not there (hallucinations)

name: Sunburn
symptoms: flake or peel - this usually happens a few days after you get sunburn

name: Superficial thrombophlebitis, see Phlebitis (superficial thrombophlebitis)
symptoms: pain, tenderness or swelling in the affected area
warm and itchy skin over the affected area
changes to the colour and texture of the surrounding skin – for example, the skin may be red and it may be thick and hard

name: Supraventricular tachycardia (SVT)
symptoms: usually lasts for a few minutes, but can sometimes last for several hours
can happen several times a day or once a year – it varies
can be triggered by tiredness, caffeine, alcohol or drugs – but often there's no obvious trigger
can happen at any age, but often starts for the first time in children and young adults – many people have their first symptoms between 25 and 40

name: Swallowing problems, see Dysphagia (swallowing problems)
symptoms: coughing or choking when eating or drinking
bringing food back up, sometimes through the nose
a feeling that food is stuck in your throat or chest
a gurgly, wet-sounding voice when eating or drinking

name: Sweat rash, see Heat rash (prickly heat)
Swollen glands
symptoms: on each side of the neck

name: Syphilis
symptoms: small sores (ulcers) on your penis, vagina, or around your bottom (anus) – these are usually painless and you may only have one of them
sores in other areas, including in your mouth or on your lips, hands or bottom
white or grey warty growths most commonly on your penis, vagina or around your anus
a rash on the palms of your hands and soles of your feet that can sometimes spread all over your body – this is not usually itchy
flu-like symptoms, such as a high temperature, headaches and tiredness
patchy hair loss on the head, beard and eyebrows

name: Tailbone (coccyx) pain
symptoms: when you sit down or stand up

name: TB, see Tuberculosis (TB)
symptoms: a cough that lasts more than 3 weeks – you may cough up mucus (phlegm) or mucus with blood in it
a high temperature or night sweats
a rash on the legs, face or other part of the body

name: Teeth grinding (bruxism)
symptoms: a painful jaw, which can lead to a condition calledtemporomandibular disorder (TMD)
worn-down or broken teeth, which can cause increased sensitivity and loss of teeth and fillings

name: Temporal arteritis
symptoms: pain or tenderness at the side of your head (temples) or on the scalp
jaw pain while eating or talking
vision problems, such asdouble visionor loss of vision in 1 or both eyes

name: Temporomandibular disorder (TMD)
symptoms: pain around your jaw, ear and temple
clicking, popping or grinding noises when you move your jaw
your jaw locking when you open your mouth

name: Tendonitis
symptoms: pain in a tendon that gets worse when you move
feeling a grating or crackling sensation when you move the tendon
swelling, sometimes with heat or redness

name: Tension headaches
symptoms: pain on both sides of your head, face or neck
feeling like something is pressing on your head or being tightened around it
the affected area may feel tender and your head may hurt more when touched

name: Tetanus
symptoms: a stiff jaw (lockjaw), which can make opening your mouth difficult
painful muscle spasms, often in your back, tummy, arms, legs, hands and feet

name: Thoracic outlet syndrome
symptoms: pins and needles – this can be worse at night and wake you up
the affected arm gets tired easily
pain and swelling in the affected arm
the affected hand and arm feels cold
the skin on the hand turns blue, grey or pale – this can be harder to see on brown or black skin

name: Throat (sore), see Sore throat
symptoms: a painful throat, especially when swallowing
redness in the back of your mouth

name: Thrush in men and women
symptoms: whitevaginal discharge(often like cottage cheese), which does not usually smell
itching and irritation around the vulva and vagina
soreness and stinging during sex or when you pee
irritation, burning and redness around the head of the penis and under the foreskin

name: TIA, see Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)
symptoms: Face– the face may have dropped on 1 side, the person may not be able to smile, or their mouth or eye may have dropped.
Arms– the person may not be able to lift both arms and keep them raised because of weakness or numbness in 1 arm.
Speech– their speech may be slurred or garbled, or the person may not be able to talk at all, despite appearing to be awake; they may also have problems understanding what you're saying to them.
Time– it's time to call 999 immediately if you see any of these signs or symptoms.

name: Tight foreskin (phimosis)
symptoms: pain when peeing or a weak flow of pee
bleeding or a thick discharge from under the foreskin or an unpleasant smell – these are signs of an infection (balanitis)
painful erections, which can make having sex difficult

name: Tongue-tie
symptoms: have difficulty attaching (latching) or staying attached to the breast or bottle teat
feed for a long time and need to be fed very often
cough, choke or make clicking noises when feeding
only take a small amount of milk at each feed
lose weight or struggle to put on weight

name: Tonsillitis
symptoms: swollen, painful glands in your neck (feels like a lump on the side of your neck)
pus-filled spots or white patches on your tonsils

name: Tooth decay
symptoms: sharp pain in your tooth when eating or drinking hot, cold or sweet things (sensitive teeth)
white, brown or black spots on your tooth

name: Toxic shock syndrome
symptoms: a raised skin rash that feels like sandpaper

name: Toxocariasis
symptoms: changes to your sight, such as seeing small dots or lines (floaters) or flashes of light

name: Transient ischaemic attack (TIA)
